name: Data collection and types of data 1

skills.name: Identify data which is primary or secondary
Identify data which is discrete, continuous or neither
Identify outliers from a list of data
Understand that larger sample sizes tend to lead to more reliable results

explanations.A: Not quite! Primary data is data collected straight from the source by a researcher. We don't know that about this data. This question is asking about the type of data we have in the table.
explanations.B: This data is discrete, as we have distinct groups of fruits and we can only buy fruit in whole numbers.
explanations.C: Not Quite! Continuous data describes data that can take any numerical value. We cannot buy 6.235 apples.
explanations.D: I think you may be thinking abut the type of table shown here, not the type of data contained within it.

explanations.A: This data is primary as the people were asked themselves, and it is quantitative as the responses given to the question (the data) will be numbers.
explanations.B: Not quite! Secondary data is data that is ready to be used which has been collected by somebody else, and qualitative data is descriptive (i.e. not a number).
explanations.C: Not Quite! Continuous data is data that can take any value. Here, the data is restricted as owners can only have a whole numbers of pets.
explanations.D: Not quite! Secondary data is data that is ready to be used which has been collected by somebody else. Is Renata using somebody else's data or is she collecting her own?

explanations.A: Not quite! Renata is asking people about their favourite colour. We are not expecting their response to be a number, therefore the data collected will not be quantitative.
explanations.B: The data is primary, as Renata is collecting it herself. The data is qualitative as the responses given to the question (the data) will be referring to the quality of something, such as a colour, not a quantity (a number).
explanations.C: Not Quite! Continuous data is data that can take any numerical value. We would not expect the response (the data) to a question asking about someone's favourite colour to be a number.
explanations.D: Not quite! Secondary data is data that is ready to be used which has been collected by somebody else. Is Renata using somebody else's data or is she collecting her own? Quantitative data is numerical, would we expect the response to what is your favourite colour to be a number?

explanations.A: Not quite! Remember, an outlier is a piece of data that is either much bigger or smaller in value than the other data points. Converting all units to mm will help you spot the outlier in this data set.
explanations.B: Converting all data points into mm, we get 90 mm, 85 mm, 7.5 mm, 70 mm and 80 mm. The 7.5 mm measurement stands out as being much smaller than the others, therefore it is an outlier in this data set.
explanations.C: Not quite! Remember, an outlier is a piece of data that is either much bigger or smaller in value than the other data points. Converting all units to mm will help you spot the outlier in this data set.
explanations.D: Not quite! Have a look again at the question. The units on the 70 is mm not cm, 70 mm = 7 cm which is similar in size to some of the other pieces of data. Converting all units to mm will help you spot the outlier in this data set.
